ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic signs and structures of conversational ASL.

I learned so much from just a semester! We're now able to have fairly long and deeper conversations about every day life. The material we learned has covered a lot of useful and helpful vocabulary that we might need on an everyday basis, and we became much more aware of Deaf culture and community. The service projects have been especially helpful in teaching us about how to create more accessible spaces and communities on campus and other places too.
Introductory ASL, introduction to Deaf culture, poetry, and theater
Signing and understanding proficiency in ASL. Learning more about Deaf community and culture and Deaf awareness.
I now have a basic understanding of ASL and can hold a conversation. Even more importantly, I have been introduced to the rich culture and history of d/Deaf and HoH individuals
I learned more about the deaf community as a whole.
how to sign common asl phrases and hold a conversation
I learned a great deal about the Deaf community and Deaf culture, as well as the importance of inclusivity and accessibility for members of Deaf community.
I learned an amazing deal in this class. I feel that I would be able to truly interact and engage in conversation with members of the Deaf community after just one semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the class was set up really well to induce learning and reviewing signs from the beginning of the week. I've never felt the pacing to be too fast, and I like the flexibility we have in class to work with partners/groups. You learn quite a lot in just a semester, so it's been really encouraging to see how much we are able to say now. I will say that there have been times when I wish the course was a bit more organized in terms of the service projects. It felt like for most of it I wasn't sure what we were supposed to be doing or how we were being coordinated but that might have been the nature of the project I chose since we didn't meet up in person.

Strengths: Great, welcoming classroom environment to be in. Amazing professor. Weaknesses: The Canvas felt a bit disorganized, and there didnt seem to be any centralized place to access all the different Google Docs with the rubrics and instructions for different things (instead, you had to find each one by clicking through different links on other Google Docs). Also, this isnt exactly a problem with the class itself, but my service project team felt pretty disorganized, although this did mean we got to have freedom and independence with our work, which has really nice.

This is an amazing course! Everything about it was great - the professor, the assignments, the class engagement, the outside of class activities. I absolutely loved this class and learned so much from it. The only weakness was the semester-long project...my project was a little disorganized, it was hard to communicate with students from other classes, so I don't think I got as much out of it as I could have. I would just suggest trying to make it more structured for future semesters.

Strengths: methods of learning, engagement levels, types of involvement, schedule (Fridays asynchronous)
Weaknesses:  none come to mind
I like how immersive the course is and how we rarely used translators, but the overall course organization was poor.
very engaging and allows for a lot of practice. weakness: none

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100%. You learn much over only a semester, and the ASL department in general is lovely. I really felt like I came away with a grasp of the language and am definitely happy I chose to take this course.

Yes, absolutely!!! I think if you are seeking to learn a language at Yale, you should definitely learn ASL. Since it isn't an oral language, it really changes your perspective on communication since it is mostly through visual and gestural means. I am someone who often gets nervous about pronouncing things wrong and gets a little anxious in speaking language courses, but ASL has been really nice since there isn't that pressure that spoken languages can have.

Yes! Everyone should learn ASL and about Deaf culture. If you can take the class with Dr. S, do so. She is so incredibly kind and understanding. I will say, I found ASL (the language, less so the class) to be very challenging to pick up, but perhaps thats just me (and learning *any* language from scratch is difficult).

Yes, I absolutely recommend!! This has been my favorite class that I've taken at Yale (I'm a senior). It has opened my eyes to disability awareness and Deaf culture. It is so rewarding to be able to sign in ASL and communicate with Deaf individuals, you never know when a skill like this could be useful. You learn so much in the span of a semester, make friends in your classes, and have such a fun time during class. This is the most engaged I've ever felt in class.
Yes 1000x tes
Yes, because it was a fun experience and i learned a lot.
yes, my favorite class so far at yale. very engaging and interesting
Definitely. Learning ASL is such an eye-opening and humbling experience.
Yes - this class is awesome and incredibly useful.
